results.title: Passion (TEFC)
results.brief_description: The rise and fall of a shopgirl (Pola Negri in her screen debut) who became the mistress of Louis XV in her ruthless pursuit of wealth and influence, was a landmark in German cinema, and a runaway box office success internationally. Great care was taken with historical accuracy in both costuming and design but Lubitsch’s primary interest was in character, plot and spectacle not in historical reconstruction. Although attacked by Left critics for ignoring the social and political significance of the Revolution, Lubitsch was not apolitical in his approach either in this film or subsequently. He maintains an ironic detachment which allows for complexity of characterisation and in his own way here portrays the realities of wealth and power. This silent film is accompanied with English intertitles.

results.title: Passion (1999)
results.creator_credit: Matt Carroll, Film Finance Corporation Australia, New South Wales Film and Television Office and Peter Duncan
results.brief_description: London, 1914, and Australian pianist and composer Percy Grainger (Richard Roxburgh) is living in London under the management of his mother, Rose (Barbara Hershey). Mother and son share an “unnatural” bond, questioned for being incestuous. Grainger is overpowered by his creative abilities at the expense of ordinary sensibilities. He has a passion for music, passion for life and sex, blatantly disregarding conventions in regards to what people expect him to play. Most significantly, he derives the most passion and pleasure from his propensity for sado-masochism, the one thing he and his mother do not agree on. Percy is introduced to pianist Karen Holten (Emily Woof) to tutor, but also to absorb the feelings he has for his mother. Rose hopes Karen will be a counterfoil to his perverse tendencies, but she is sorely mistaken. Musings on the differences between lust, admiration, friendship and what it means to love are also covered in this biopic of a musician and painter equally known for his peccadillos and fondness for leisurewear. Based on the play “Percy & Rose” written by Rob George.

results.title: Passing the know-how along
results.brief_description: Provides some ideas for the experienced worker to help and guide and new worker in their job. Analyse and plan your instructions; select key points where real skill is required and stress these points; show how to do it; let the person watch you do it again; let them do the simple parts of the job; help with do the whole job with constructive advice; let them do the whole job but watch; put them on their own. Adapted from a bulletin of the Training within Industry Section of the Office of Production Management entitled “Helping the experienced worker to break in a man on a new job”. A National Defence film.

results.title: Passing moments
results.brief_description:
Fade in, fade out. The present moment never lasts. Everything you see and feel right now will leave you…. The five vignettes are all shot during one train journey through the Madhya Pradesh state of India. The camera lense lingers briefly, in slow motion, on the passing landscapes and inhabitants - capturing the mood and movements of the outside world.
Soundtrack recorded and produced by Sami Ramir.

results.title: Passing era of the steam horse [B&W]
results.brief_description: Steam locomotives have been replaced by diesels on the Victorian Railways. Their history in the system is briefly covered, and various types are shown in operation, concluding with the narrow gauge service from Ferntree Gully to Gembrook being restored as a tourist feature.

results.title: Passe Ton Bac D'abord = Graduate First
results.brief_description:
In a provincial city in the mining region of Northern France, a group of disillusioned students with no prospects other than dead-end jobs or unemployment, see little point in doing any work for their ‘baccalaureat’ (high school certificate). Ignoring the futile dissertations of their teachers, they drift aimlesslly round the local bistro or down the coast; some engage in hollow sexual encounters; others go to Paris. Pialat’s minutely detailed observation of dispossessed youth is made with an admirable combination of objectivity and compassion.

Credits: Producer, Maurice Pialat ; director, Maurice Pialat ; writer, Maurice Pialat ; photography, Pierre-William Glenn ; music, Patrick Juvet.
Cast: Sabine Haudepin, Philippe Marland, Valerie Chassigneux, Annick Alane, Michel Caron.

results.title: Passage through The Wall
results.brief_description: A report on the short period when West Berliners were allowed to visit their relatives in East Berlin, Christmas 1963. It was the first time after more than two years that they were able to do so. East Berliners are sill not allowed to visit East Berlin.
results.description: A report on the short period when West Berliners were allowed to visit their relatives in East Berlin, Christmas 1963. It was the first time after more than two years that they were able to do so. East Berliners are sill not allowed to visit East Berlin.

results.title: Passage home
results.creator_credit: Julian Wintle, Group Film Productions and Roy Baker
results.brief_description: The steamer, “Bulinga” is the setting of this tense journey which takes the viewer on a passage from South America to England. The steamer is laden with pedigree bulls and Captain Lucky Ryland (Peter Finch) is pushing his crew to complete the trip in record breaking time. Adding to Lucky’s lack of cohesion with his crew members is the presence of Ruth (Diane Cilento), a passenger they have received orders to carry. Lucky raises the wrath of the first mate when he saves Ruth from being attacked by Lucky during one of his drunken binges. Lucky becomes isolated from the rest of the crew and shirks away from his responsibilities, until a violent storm hits the boat and they must put aside their differences to work as a team and survive. Cast also includes Anthony Steel, Cyril Cusack, Geoffrey Keen and Hugh Griffith. Based on a novel by Richard Armstrong.

results.title: Pass the word
results.creator_credit: Epilepsy Foundation of America and Dave Gilbert
results.brief_description: Epileptics face discrimination in the area of employment. Employees are reluctant to take on an epileptic, usually for reasons of job safety and insurance, this occurs especially in the manufacturing areas of employment. This film aims to improve the image of the epileptic, and to show that he is a valuable and productive member of the workforce.
